Vegetarian "Beef" Broth

Courses:
Categories:
Collections:
Source: https://www.cookscountry.com/recipes/8842-vegetarian-beef-broth
Serving size: 1/2 cup
Preparation time:
Cooking time:

Ingredients

2 ounces button mushrooms, sliced thin

2 TBSP dehydrated onion

1TBSP dehydrated celery

1TBSP dehydrated carrot

1/4 tablespoon vegetable oil

1/8 tsp pumpkin powder

1/8 tsp carrot powder

1/8 tsp beet powder

1/8 tsp Himalayan salt to taste

1/8 tsp citric acid

1 TBSP hot water

1/8 tsp garlic

1 cup and 3/4 tablespoon water

1/4 teaspoon sea salt

Directions

1. Adjust oven rack to middle position and heat oven to 450 degrees. Combine mushrooms, onion, celery, carrot, oil, tomato paste, and garlic in large roasting pan.

2. Roast until vegetables are tender and very dark in color, 35 to 40 minutes. Add water to pan. Continue to roast until water is reduced by half, about 30 minutes. Strain through fine-mesh strainer and discard solids. Stir in salt and let cool completely. Broth can be refrigerated for 3 days or frozen for up to 1 month.

Photos

Vegetarian Boston Baked Beans With Molasses Recipe

Courses: Entree
Categories: 09 🥕
Collections:
Source: https://www.thespruceeats.com/vegetarian-boston-baked-beans-with-molasses-3377176
Serving size: 6 Portions (6 Servings)
Preparation time: 10 mins
Cooking time: 1 hour 15 mins

Ingredients

3 cups navy beans (or pinto beans, pre-cooked or from a can)

1/2 cup molasses

1 cup vegetable broth

1 yellow onion (diced)

1 cup tomato paste

1 tablespoon tamari

1 teaspoon mustard powder

1/2 teaspoon garlic powder

Directions

1. Gather the ingredients.

2. Pre-heat the oven to 350 F.

3. In a large casserole or baking dish, stir together all of the ingredients, mixing well to combine.

4. Cover, bake for one hour. If baked beans are too saucy, bake uncovered for an additional 15 minutes.

5. Serve your homemade baked beans along with some homemade  vegan skillet cornbread .

Nutrition

Amount per serving
Serving size: 6 Portions (6 Servings)
Calories: 474
Total Fat: 2g
Saturated Fat: 0g
Cholesterol: 0mg
Sodium: 336mg
Total Carbohydrate: 94g
Dietary Fiber: 21g
Protein: 25g

Photos

Vegetarian Chicken Stock

Courses:
Categories:
Collections:
Source: https://ohmyveggies.com/vegetarian-chicken-stock/
Serving size: About 2 quarts
Preparation time: 5 mins
Cooking time: 2 hours

Ingredients

1 large onion, quartered

4 large carrots, trimmed and cut into large pieces

4 ribs celery, trimmed and cut into large pieces

2 leeks, white and pale green parts only, halved and rinsed well

2 cloves garlic, smashed

8 sprigs thyme

8 sprigs parsley

1 bay leaf

5 whole white peppercorns

18 cups water

1 teaspoon ground turmeric

Sea Salt

Directions

1. Combine all of the ingredients through the water in a large stockpot over high heat. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low. Simmer for 2 hours, then stir in the turmeric. Let the stock cool.

2. Once cooled, set a fine mesh strainer over a large bowl or a second stockpot. Pour the stock through the strainer, then use the back of a wooden spoon to mash the vegetables to release as much liquid as possible. Discard the solids. If you're making broth, add salt to taste. Use the stock immediately or freeze in airtight plastic containers or freezer bags.

Photos

Vickys Rice Crumb, Gluten-Free Breadcrumb Substitute

Courses:
Categories:
Collections:
Source: https://cookpad.com/us/recipes/345578-vickys-rice-crumb-gluten-free-breadcrumb-substitute
Serving size:
Preparation time:
Cooking time: 6 hours

Ingredients

55 grams dry brown rice per 1lb meat/poultry

OR

50 grams dry white rice per 1lb meat/poultry

Directions

Cook 1 cup brown rice.

Dehydrate 125° F - 5 HR

Whirl in the Blendtec.

1. Cook your rice by packet instruction in a large pan of boiling water. The crumbs will keep well so don't be afraid to make more than you need

2. *165g / 1 cup of dry brown rice will make enough crumbs to coat 3lbs of meat/poultry. Likewise 150g / 1 cup dry long grain white is enough for the same

3. Preheat your oven to gas 1/2 (half) / 120C / 250°F and when the rice is cooked, spread it in a single layer onto a baking tray

4. Bake for 20 minutes or so until dried then let cool

5. Put the cooled rice into a blender or coffee grinder and grind it into a fine crumb consistency

6. Store in a glass jar with a lid in a cool dark place or in the fridge

7. Use in place of breadcrumbs in any recipe requiring them such as meatloaf, breaded fish fillets or chicken strips, stuffed mushrooms, a crust for a roast, stuffing etc

Photos

Vidalia Onion Upside Down Cornbread

Courses:
Categories:
Collections:
Source: https://sweetsavant.com/cornbread/
Serving size:
Preparation time:
Cooking time:

Ingredients

• 2 Vidalia Onions

• 4 tablespoons of butter

• 12 cups of fine ground yellow or white cornmeal, I used yellow

• 1 cup all purpose flour

• 1 and 12 teaspoons kosher salt

• 73 cup white sugar

• 1 tablespoon baking powder

• 8 ounces frozen broccoli-thawed

• 12 cup cooked chopped bacon (optional)

• 4 eggs

• 16 ounces of 2% cottage cheese

Directions

Instructions

1. Preheat the oven to 400 degrees 2. Slice the Vidalia Onions into rings leaving the rings in order if possible 3. Melt the butter in the cast iron skillet 4. Place the onion slices close together into the butter, fill in any spaces with smaller bits of onion 5. Finely chop any remaining Vidalia onion and reserve it.

6. Let the onions cook on medium heat for 5 minutes 7. While the onions are cooking mix the batter: 8. Add the cornmeal, flour, sugar, salt and baking powder in a bowl and stir to combine.

9. In a large bowl beat 4 eggs, mix in the cottage cheese 10. Squeeze the water out of the broccoli and mix this into the eggs. Add the reserved chopped onions 11. Add the cornmeal mix and stir to combine. (add optional bacon if you like) 12. Pour the batter over the onions 13. Bake the cornbread for 20-23 minutes or until done.

14. Let the cornbread cool for 10-15 minutes. Run a knife around the edge of the cornbread.

15. Place a plate over the pan and using oven mitts carefully flip the pan over and remove the cornbread from the pan Recipe by Sweet Savant at https://sweetsavant.com/2015/07/29/vidalia-onion-upside-down-broccoli-cornbread/

Photos

Vinegar-Free Mayonnaise 

Courses:
Categories:
Collections:
Source:
Serving size: 20 tbsp
Preparation time:
Cooking time:

Ingredients

1 organic egg 

2 Tbsp fresh lemon juice 

½ tsp dry mustard 

¼ teaspoon seasoned salt 

1 cup olive oil

Directions

Blend first 4 ingredients.

With blender running constantly, slowly dribble in the oil, a little at a time, until it's thick and creamy.

It will become slightly thicker when refrigerated.

Welch’s Grape Juice Wine Recipe

Courses:
Categories:
Collections:
Source: https://www.leaf.tv/articles/how-to-make-homemade-wine-using-welchs-grape-juice/
Serving size:
Preparation time:
Cooking time:

Ingredients

2 64 OZ bottles Welch’s 100 percent grape juice

1 cup cane sugar

1 tablespoon wine yeast

Directions

In a large stainless steel saucepan over medium heat, add grape juice and cane sugar.

Stir until sugar is completely dissolved.

Let grape juice mixture cool to room temperature.

Add in wine yeast and mix to combine.

Transfer to a fermentation jug like a carboy with an airlock. Store in a cool, dark place for fermentation to occur.

For the first 24 hours, shake the carboy twice a day to let out the carbon dioxide.

The homemade wine using Welch’s grape juice will take about a week to be ready. You will know when fermentation is done when there’s no more carbon dioxide fizzing off the top, you can smell the wine, and the yeast sediment has settled to the bottom of the jug.

If you want a stronger wine, leave undisturbed in a dark area for up to a month.

Strain the homemade wine and transfer it to an old wine bottle for storage.

Notes

1 TBSP oak chips added after fermentation for 1 week, strain for Merlot flavo.

Photos

Welch’s Grape Juice Wine Tweaked

Courses:
Categories:
Collections:
Source: https://www.leaf.tv/articles/how-to-make-homemade-wine-using-welchs-grape-juice/
Serving size:
Preparation time:
Cooking time:

Ingredients

2 cans frozen juice concentrate

6 cans filtered water

1 cup sugar

1 gram wine yeast

1 tablespoon oak chips

Divided up as follows:

Yeast Rehydration

2 TBSP Juice Concentrate

3 Ounces Filtered Water

1 GM Wine Yeast

Sugar

1 Cup Sugar

1 Cup Reconstituted Juice

Must

Remainder of juice from yeast and sugar

1 full can of juice.

Water to reconstitute

1 tbsp. oak chips

Directions

Set up sous vide for 104° F

Using 1 4 Oz Mason jar per batch:

Add Juice (2 TBSP)

Filtered Water (3 Oz)

With seal and ring finger tight, place in bath to warm up.

Remove jar from bath, sprinkle yeast and stir. Place back in the bath for 15 minutes.

Remove and cool to 10° F above temp of must.

TRY:

8 oz Mason jar per batch:

1 cup reconstituted juice

1 cup sugar.

If it doesn't fit, upsize to 16 Oz jars.

104° F For as long as it takes to dissolve sugar.

In 4 liter jugs:

Add must and dissolved sugar and juice. Holding back some must to rinse yeast and sugar jars.

When yeast is cooled to 10° F above temperature of must, add in yeast to jugs.

Add airlocks and leave to ferment for 5 days.

Rack on fifth day.

Notes

1 TBSP oak chips added after fermentation for 1 week, strain for Merlot flavor.

Dry wines are typically in the 0.2%-0.3% BRIX range. Sweet is higher. Solution If Brix too high, water it down or maybe add unsweetened cranberry juice?

Photos

Whipped Whole Milk Ricotta Recipe

Courses:
Categories:
Collections:
Source: https://www.vacmasterfresh.com/fresh-bites-blog/sous-vide-ricotta-cheese-recipe/
Serving size:
Preparation time:
Cooking time:

Ingredients

1 cup whole milk sous vide ricotta, see recipe

1 tablespoon sous vide garlic oil, see recipe

1 tablespoon of sous vide garlic puree, or to taste, see recipe

1 tablespoon freshly squeezed lemon juice

1 tablespoon lemon zest

1/4 teaspoon salt, kosher, or to taste

Directions

1. Combine the ricotta, garlic oil, lemon juice, zest, salt, in a food processor with metal blade or a blender

2. Blend for 2 minutes or until silky smooth in the food processor or blender, stopping to scrape down the sides of the container once or twice with a spatula.

3. Use right away or vacuum seal and store in the refrigerator.

White Bean Hummus

Courses: Snack
Categories:
Collections:
Source: https://www.yummly.com/recipe/White-Bean-Hummus-1401136?utm_medium=yummly_amp_site&utm_source=yummly_amp_site
Serving size: 4 servings
Preparation time:
Cooking time:

Ingredients

14 ounces cannellini beans rinsed

2 ounces ground almonds

2 teaspoons fresh lemon juice

2 cloves garlic crushed

1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil plus extra, for drizzling

Directions

1. Process beans, almonds, lemon juice and garlic in a food processor until smooth. With motor running, gradually add the olive oil until thick and creamy. Transfer mixture to a saucepan. Stir over low heat until warm. Season with salt. Transfer to a serving dish. Drizzle with oil to serve.

White Chocolate Fudge

Courses: Dessert
Categories:
Collections:
Source: https://www.plantpowercouple.com/recipes/vegan-white-chocolate-fudge/
Serving size:
Preparation time:
Cooking time:

Ingredients

2/3 cup cocoa butter, melted

1/2 cup ghee, melted

1/2 cup unsweetened almond cream

1/2 cup unsweetened vanilla soy protein powder (or sub more powdered sugar)

1/2 tsp salt

2 cups powdered sugar

Directions

1. First, melt your cocoa butter followed by the ghee. You can do this on the stove or in the microwave, but be sure to keep it at a low heat and stir often. Measure each of them in their melted forms and add them to a large mixing bowl.

2. Add the almond cream, protein powder, and sea salt to your mixing bowl. Use your hand or stand mixer on low to combine these ingredients. Then, mix in the powdered sugar, 1/2 cup at a time. Once all the sugar is incorporated, turn the mixer to high and beat for about a minute. This part is vital, as you want the ingredients to completely emulsify.

3. Next, Line a 9x9 baking dish (or any dish of a similar size) with parchment or plastic wrap. This will help you pull the fudge out easily. Pour the fudge mixture into the dish, using a rubber spatula to make sure you get allllll of it. Set this in the fridge overnight to set. Alternatively, you can freeze it for 1-2 hours, but the texture is better in the fridge.

4. When ready, carefully pull the fudge out of the dish using the parchment. Slice it on a cutting board into whatever shapes / sized you want and enjoy! Leftovers can be stored in an air-tight container in the fridge for a week or the freezer for up to a month (if you can last that long, lol!).

Nutrition

Amount per serving
Calories: 3446
Total Fat: 257g
Saturated Fat: 191g
Cholesterol: 327mg
Sodium: 2174mg
Total Carbohydrate: 306g
Sugars: 275g
Protein: 4g

Photos

White Rice for One

Courses: Side Dish
Categories:
Collections:
Source: http://www.cooking-4-one.com/2017/11/21/white-rice-for-one/
Serving size: 1
Preparation time: 5 mins
Cooking time: 25 mins

Ingredients

½ cup white rice

½ cup water or broth

⅛ tsp salt

any spices or flavorings desired

Directions

1. Set up the sous vide water bath for 200 degrees F.

2. Rinse the rice to remove any surface starch.

3. In a recloseable bag, add the rice, salt, seasonings (if desired), and water (or broth).

4. Using the water displacement method, remove as much air as possible before closing.

5. Place the bag into the water bath and clip to the side.

6. After 25 minutes, remove the bag and empty into a bowl.

7. Lightly fluff the rice with a fork.

Notes

For the slow cooker function on your instant pot the low an is about 170 degrees, normal is 200 degrees, and high is 210 degrees.

Photos

Whole Chicken (ELPAF)

Courses: Entree
Categories: 02 🐔, 07 🧈
Collections:
Source: https://superwaveovenrecipes.com/whole-chicken-emeril-lagasse-pressure-air-fryer-duet-recipe/
Serving size:
Preparation time:
Cooking time:

Ingredients

7 pound whole chicken, thawed

1 cup of chicken stock

Poultry seasoning of choice

sea salt

Extra virgin olive oil

Directions

Pressure Cook ELPAF Poultry 40 minutes

Quick Release

Air Fry Poultry 325° F 13 minutes

Remove any innards from the chicken.

Cover the chicken with oil.

Cover the chicken with spices.

Put the wire rack into the pot.

Pour in 1 cup of chicken stock.

Put the chicken into the pot on the rack.

Place the pressure cook lid onto the Emeril Pressure Air Fryer.

Lock the lid so it is sealed.

Press the Pressure button and turn the dial to Poultry. Then press the dial button in to select that option.

Press the Time button and adjust the cooking time to 40 minutes.

(Rule of thumb is about 6 minutes per pound. In this case, the cook will finish fully during the later air frying phase.)

Press the dial in to start the cook.

(It may take about 9 minutes to fully pressurize.)

When the cooking time completes press the Cancel button and release the pressure, for a rapid release. Use caution when releasing pressure.

Check the meat temperature, it should be about 155° F. or greater

Remove the chicken from the pot and place it in a pan.

Using pot holders empty out the fluids in the pot. Rinse and dry the pot with paper towels.

(You may save the fluid for other dishes that need a broth.)

Place the pot back into the Emeril Pressure Air Fryer.

Insert the wire rack.

Place the chicken onto the wire rack.

Put on the air fry lid.

Press the Air Fry button and turn the dial to Poultry.

Press the dial in, and then press the Temp button and adjust the cooking temperature to 325° F..

Press the Time button and adjust the cooking time to 13 minutes. (With the additional 2 minutes of air fryer fan cool down time, this will result in a total of 15 minutes the chicken will be in the air fryer.)

Press the dial in to start the air frying.

Once the air fryer fan cool down is finished, the screen turns blue and it starts beeping. Press the Cancel button twice to end the cook.

Check the meat temperature is at least 165° F. in the breast and thigh.

Remove the seared chicken.

Enjoy!

Photos

Whole Egg Mayonnaise Sous Vide

Courses:
Categories:
Collections:
Source: https://www.vacmasterfresh.com/fresh-bites-blog/whole-egg-mayonnaise-sous-vide/
Serving size:
Preparation time:
Cooking time:

Ingredients

2 pasteurized eggs sous vide, see recipe (above)

1 tablespoon Dijon mustard

4 teaspoons fresh lemon juice or high quality vinegar

1 cup vegetable oil

Kosher salt

Black pepper

Directions

1. Crack and place the whole eggs in a medium sized bowl or in the bowl a food processor or bar blender.

2. Add mustard and lemon juice.

3. Using an immersion blender or other machine blend ingredients for a second or so until well combined.

4. With motor running, add oil in a slow, steady stream (mixture should become thick and emulsified).

5. Season to taste with the salt and pepper.

Photos

Whole Pie Pumpkin

Courses:
Categories:
Collections:
Source: Facebook
Serving size:
Preparation time:
Cooking time:

Ingredients

1 pie pumpkin

1 cup water

Directions

I do this every year!!!

$1.19 for a can of pumpkin purée OR 3 pie pumpkins for $5 (or $1.67 each and get 2 cans+ worth of purée from EACH pumpkin!!)

Put whole pie pumpkin (I have an 8qt) in with 1 cup of water.

Cook for 17 min QR or NPR, doesn't matter. I had to bathe the kids, so it sat a while.

The stem pops right off and the skin peels like butter.

Cut in half

Scrape out pulp and seeds (SUPER easy)

....we save the seeds to roast with EVOO, garlic salt and rosemary. Delish

Mash with a fork or pulse in the blender.

2 Dairy free, gluten free, Paleo pumpkin pies coming up tomorrow!!!!!

It's also great in oatmeal, pancake batter, waffle batter, muffins, etc.

When the pie pumpkins go on clearance after Thanksgiving, I buy like 10 and get to work cooking and freezing to last us until the fall again!!

5 year old is playing a math game on the computer in the background if your sound is on. 😜

Photos

Whole Wheat English Muffins Recipe | Lindley Mills Super Sprout™

Courses:
Categories:
Collections:
Source: https://pastrychefonline.com/whole-wheat-english-muffins/
Serving size: 16
Preparation time: 15 mins
Cooking time: 30 mins

Ingredients

17-18 oz (2 cups, 2 Tablespoons- 2 1/4 cups) lukewarm milk (I used whole milk)

3 Tablespoons softened unsalted butter

1 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt

2 Tablespoons sugar, (I used demerara, or Sugar in the Raw)

19 oz Lindley Mills Super Sprout Whole Wheat Flour for Baking, (or other bread flour--reduce milk to 14-15 oz)

1 large egg

2 teaspoons active dry yeast, (instant is fine here too)

semolina or farina, (Cream of Wheat) for sprinkling on the griddle

Directions

1. Combine all the dough ingredients in the order given in the bowl of your stand mixer.

2. Mix with the paddle attachment for about 5 minutes, or until shiny, smooth and very elastic.

3. Scrape the dough into a ball in the bottom of the mixer bowl, cover and let rise in a warm place until doubled, about 2 hours.

4. Generously sprinkle your griddle or skillets or electric frying pans or whatever you're using with the farina or semolina (I used semolina. King Arthur says you can use either without any problem). Set them aside.

5. Portion dough into 16 equal portions (or 12 for burger buns). I do this by weighing my finished dough and then dividing that weight by the number of portions. Then I use my bench knife and scale to cut the dough and weigh out each portion.

6. Once you have your dough scaled, gently shape each portion into a flat-ish round about 3" in diameter. Place in the prepared pan/s. They can be close together, but you don't want them to touch.

7. If you only have one pan to cook in, place the extra rounds on a parchment-lined and semolina-dusted cookie sheet and cover them until it's their turn.

8. Cover the shaped muffins (on the griddle and on the cookie sheet, if you needed "overflow" space), and allow them to rest 20-30 minutes, until just slightly puffy.

9. Remove the towel, turn the heat on medium low and gently cook the muffins for several minutes on each side. I flipped mine multiple times after an initial 7-ish minutes a side. Regulate the heat so they don't cook too quickly and watch them carefully. The semolina will eventually get dark but should insulate the muffins enough to keep them from burning as long as you set your heat fairly low.

10. Every once in a while, go in through the side of a couple of muffins to check the internal temperature. You want them to reach 200F.

11. This took me 40 minutes, more or less, but it will most likely take you less time since you're using more liquid than I did. Just keep an eye on them and make sure you have a good instant read thermometer.

12. Remove to cool on racks. Split the muffins with a fork before toasting. Enjoy with sweet or savory toppings.

Nutrition

Amount per serving
Serving size: 1 muffin
Calories: 167
Total Fat: 4g
Saturated Fat: 2g
Cholesterol: 21mg
Sodium: 234mg
Total Carbohydrate: 26g
Dietary Fiber: 2g
Sugars: 2g
Protein: 7g

Photos

Wild Alaska Pollock Curry

Courses:
Categories:
Collections:
Source: https://www.alaskaseafood.org/recipe/wild-alaska-pollock-coconut-curry-with-cucumber-yogurt-sauce/
Serving size: 4
Preparation time: 15 mins
Cooking time: 15 mins

Ingredients

2 tablespoons olive oil

1 medium onion, chopped (about 1½ cups)

1 teaspoon minced garlic

1 teaspoon grated fresh ginger

1 teaspoon black cumin (nigella) seeds

1 teaspoon ground turmeric

1 cup cauliflower florets

1 cup broccoli florets

14 ounces oat milk

2 ounces melted clarified butter

16 ounces wild Alaskan pollock fillets, cut into ½-inch pieces

1½ teaspoons salt

Steamed basmati rice, for serving

Directions

1. <p>Heat olive oil in a large sauté pan over medium heat. Add the onion and cook until softened, about 3 minutes. Add the garlic and ginger and sauté for a minute until fragrant. Add the turmeric and black cumin seeds.</p>

2. <p>Add the cauliflower, broccoli, and bell pepper and toss to coat in spices. Pour in the coconut milk and serrano pepper (if using) and bring to a low simmer. Cover and simmer for 5 minutes.</p>

3. <p>Place the wild Alaska pollock and 1 teaspoon salt into the pan. Simmer for 5 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through.</p>

4. <p>In a bowl mix together the yogurt, cucumber, remaining ½ teaspoon salt, and garam masala.</p>

5. <p>Serve wild Alaska pollock coconut curry spooned over steamed basmati rice with the yogurt cucumber sauce on the side or on top.</p>

Nutrition

Amount per serving
Calories: 413

Photos

Wild Rice and Mushroom Instant Pot Soup

Courses: Entree
Categories:
Collections:
Source: https://www.berlyskitchen.com/wild-rice-mushroom-instant-pot-soup/
Serving size: 8 Servings
Preparation time: 10 mins
Cooking time: 35 mins

Ingredients

3 Stalks Celery ((chopped))

3 Large Carrots ((chopped))

1 Small White Onion ((diced))

8 Ounces Mushrooms ((sliced))

4 Cloves Garlic ((minced))

4 Cups Chicken Broth ((or Vegetable Broth))

1 Cup Wild Rice ((well rinsed))

1 Teaspoon Poultry Seasoning

1 Teaspoon Sea Salt

2 Sprigs Fresh Thyme

2 Large Bay Leaves

8 Tablespoons Unsalted Butter ((one stick))

3/4 Cup All-Purpose Flour

1 Cup Whole Milk

Directions

Step One, place all soup ingredients into the Instant Pot making sure to pour the rice on top. Do NOT add the roux ingredients.

Step Two, use a spoon or spatula to press down the rice so it’s submerged in the broth.

Step Three, close the lid and set the Instant Pot to “Sealing.”

Step Four, choose the manual pressure/pressure cook option setting for 35 minutes. After the cook time is finished, allow the Instant Pot to complete a 10 minute natural release before opening the valve for a quick release.

Step Five, while the soup cooks, make the roux. Melt the butter in a medium-sized saucepan, then add the flour. Whisk constantly to incorporate the flour and make a smooth consistency. The longer the roux cooks, the darker in color it will become. Cook for about 5-7 minutes, just long enough to eliminate the raw flour taste.

Step Six, add the milk to the roux and whisk to combine. Remove from heat.

Step Seven, after the soup finishes in the Instant Pot, carefully add the roux. Stir to combine and remove the bay leaves and thyme stems. The soup should thicken and have a creamy texture.

Step Eight, serve immediately.

Nutrition

Amount per serving
Serving size: 1 serving
Calories: 266
Total Fat: 13g
Saturated Fat: 7g
Cholesterol: 33mg
Sodium: 769mg
Total Carbohydrate: 31g
Dietary Fiber: 3g
Sugars: 4g
Protein: 7g

Photos

Wine in Just One Week

Courses:
Categories:
Collections:
Source: https://delishably.com/beverages/How_To_Make_Drinkable_Wine_In_Just_One_Week
Serving size: Makes a great light body wine.
Preparation time:
Cooking time:

Ingredients

1 cup of granulated sugar

1 gallon of whatever juice you like

1 packet of yeast

Directions

1. Buy grape juice. Grape is all I have ever experimented with, except for one batch of apple. Different types of juice will probably produce different types of wine since each type of fruit has a different sugar content. I have used Sam's Choice and the Great Value brand from Wal-Mart, but you can use Welch's or any other brand.

2. I recommend using one gallon of juice, but you can use a smaller bottle if you'd like. Look for "100% Juice" on the label. It will always say "from concentrate." Yeast will not do its job with preservatives present. Ascorbic acid and citric acid (Vitamin C) are ok. All grape juices are concentrated with water, so you'll never be able to get pure juice unless you squeeze the grapes yourself.

3. Set the juice out so it gets to room temperature. Juice should be at room temperature or slightly higher. If your juice is refrigerated, you need to leave it sitting out until it reaches room temp.

4. Add one packet of active dry baker's yeast. Red Star and Fleichman's are the two brands I see the most in my local grocery stores. Do not stir. Do not add more yeast later; just this once. I generally follow this yeast rule about adding yeast just once; however, I should say that in several batches I have refreshed the yeast by adding a teaspoon's worth. My advice is that if after about 3 days there is no more bubbling, add some more yeast. If this doesn't start some new bubbling activity, it is done, and you should allow this extra yeast time to settle to the bottom sediment. Finish by transferring to your final container.

5. Bottle it and leave room for air. Screw the cap back on the bottle and loosen about one turn so air can escape. Fermentation produces carbon dioxide and needs to be able to vent from the bottle. I used to use a balloon, but other winemakers have suggested this should not be done because acids and other nasty things can build up in the balloon and fall back into the bottle. Makes sense to me.

6. Keep an eye on it. Watch your project daily. After 3 days, check to see if it's still bubbling. If it has stopped, you can sample it now. If it's still bubbling, just keep checking it daily until it isn't bubbling anymore. If you really can't see any bubble action, put your ear to it and listen.

7. When the Wine Is Finished

8. Find a glass container. When you are satisfied that your wine is ready to drink, transfer the wine from your fermentation container/original bottle to another clean container of plastic or glass. Old, sterilized glass wine bottles are perfect.

9. Transfer wine without upsetting the sediment. When transferring the wine, use a plastic funnel. Once you've tipped the wine to pour, DO NOT turn the bottle back up straight but keep pouring until you're finished. There is sediment left over at the bottom that contains acids and impurities. If you keep tipping the bottle, you'll stir up the sediment and ruin the wine. Siphoning with a hose would be just as good or even better, just leave the end of the hose an inch or so above the sediment to avoid sucking it out with the good stuff.

10. Refrigerate and enjoy. After bottling your brew, it is suggested that you refrigerate but leaving out at room temperature is ok as long as your room temperature is not really hot. Keep out of direct sunlight.

11. Please drink responsibly, and enjoy the fruits of your labor.

12. More Things to Keep in Mind

13. Juice produces ethanol, not methanol: Making homemade wine, or alcohol in general, is simple because of the simple fact that yeast converts sugar to ethanol (alcohol). There is a misconception that drinking homemade brew is not safe, but that's only if you drink methanol. Brewing with fruit juices and yeast cannot produce methanol. It can only produce ethanol.

14. This process can be done in as little as three days: My attempts at wine making usually take around 7 days, but some people who have tried this method have reported that the fermentation (yeast completely stopped making bubbles) stopped in about 3 days. So this method can actually produce wine with a moderate alcohol content in about 3 days.

15. You might need to add sugar: Since this fermentation method produces wine that isn't very sweet (because the yeast converted all the sugar in the juice to alcohol), I am updating my recipe by saying that you should add one cup of granulated or cane sugar or corn syrup to a one gallon batch or half a cup to a half gallon batch before adding the yeast. This might produce a sweeter wine, if that's what you want. It might be best to pour the juice into a large saucepan and heat it up slightly (not over 110 degrees F) so the sugar will dissolve properly. Then pour it back into the bottle using a funnel and allow to cool to room temperature.

16. A hydrometer will tell you the alcohol content: I'm not sure of the alcohol content of this brew, but you could buy a hydrometer to measure it. They are cheap and readily available online or at any brewer's store.

17. Get winemaking yeast, if possible: If you live in a city that has a home-brewing supply, I advise buying yeast made just for winemaking. Active baker's yeast from grocery stores works ok, but the real winemaking yeast is formulated better for wine, doesn't peter out as fast, and will add a few days to my "one week" method. I have never experienced a "bread smell" using baker's yeast.

18. Comments

19. Elizabeth on August 12, 2020:

20. Made wine per your recipe, easier than any other that I tried. 100% tropical juice for me is best. Thanks for your expertise. Drinking seventh day, in time will let it go longer. The milder buzz is better for me, don't take much for my in grown high spirit.

Photos

Worcestershire Sauce

Courses:
Categories:
Collections:
Source: https://www.geniuskitchen.com/recipe/homemade-worcestershire-sauce-278956
Serving size: 12 serving(s)
Preparation time: 2 mins
Cooking time: 10 mins

Ingredients

2/3 cup water

2 tablespoons low sodium tamari

2 teaspoons citric acid

1/2 tablespoon molasses

1/4 teaspoon ground ginger

1/4 teaspoon mustard powder

1/4 teaspoon onion powder

1/4 teaspoon garlic powder

1/8 teaspoon cinnamon

Directions

1. Place all ingredients in a medium saucepan and stir thoroughly. Bring to a boil, stirring constantly. Simmer 1 minute. Cool.

2. Store in the refrigerator.

Nutrition

Amount per serving
Calories: 8.7
Total Fat: 0g
Saturated Fat: 0g
Cholesterol: 0mg
Sodium: 89.8mg
Total Carbohydrate: 1.6g
Dietary Fiber: 0.1g
Sugars: 1.2g
Protein: 0.2g

Photos

Yellow curry

Courses: Entree
Categories:
Collections:
Source:
Serving size: 1
Preparation time: 20 mins
Cooking time: 20 mins

Ingredients

1 tbsp ghee

1 tbsp almond flour

2 tsp curry powder

1/2 tsp Ginger

1/2 tsp garlic

1/4 tsp tumeric

1 cup almond milk

1 cup California vegetables

1/4 cup frozen peas

2 cups water or more

1 tsp sea salt

1/4 cup brown basmati rice, thoroughly rinsed

Directions

Cut California vegetables into bite-size pieces.

Over medium-high heat make roux, and add spices. Add almond milk whisking to keep smooth.

Add vegetables and heat through.

Serve with cooked brown rice.

Photos

Yellow curry with tempeh

Courses: Entree
Categories: 09 🥕
Collections:
Source:
Serving size: 1
Preparation time: 20 mins
Cooking time: 20 mins

Ingredients

1 tbsp ghee

1 tbsp almond flour

2 tsp curry powder

1/2 tsp Ginger

1/2 tsp garlic

1/4 tsp tumeric

1 cup almond milk

1 cup California vegetables

1/4 cup peas

1/4 package tempeh cubed, steamed and pan fried ( or oiled and bake in Nuwave)

2 cups water or more

1 tsp sea salt

1/4 cup brown basmati rice, thoroughly rinsed

Directions

Steam tempeh for 10 minutes. Pat dry, cut into cubes, toss in olive oil and bake in NuWave oven for 5 minutes.

Cut California vegetables into bite-size pieces.

Over medium-high heat make roux, and add spices. Add almond milk whisking to keep smooth.

Add vegetables and tempeh and heat through.

Serve with cooked brown rice.

Photos
